subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: New file uploaded to Read_Alphabet
msgSnippet: I have poor vertical discipline when I’m scribbling in my diary, so I was thrown by what I read as “holy cam of God” in William Blake’s poem. ...
messageBody:
I have poor vertical discipline when I’m scribbling in my diary, so I was thrown by what I read as “holy cam of God” in William Blake’s poem.

AFAICT, letter-joining was important to him, but not everything. Have a look at the first couple of paragraphs of page 13 (emphasis added by me):

Letter joining is not a virtue in itself, but where it can be done without added strokes fo the pen it avoids the slight but cumulative actions of lifting the pen and moving the hand to a fresh starting point.

[…]These are the only points at which joining is allowed, and done without meaningless and confusing link-strokes. A few examples will enable such opportunities to be foreseen and taken with many other letters but not with all. Never attempt connections midway between the parallels: breaks are less confusing.

Sounds like Read thinks that joining letters can be handy, but not all the time.

Also, Read already has a backwards-·low — it’s ·llan, at the very bottom of page 8.

On May 23, 2018, at 3:24 PM, gpdiqhfx45cwvckybgkazrwe22guir3me33fnyth@... [Read_Alphabet] <Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com> wrote:


Paige,

I had the impression from reading and re-reading the Manual that Read thought minimizing penlifts was fairly important.  Doing so seems, on page 14 of the Manual, to be the driving force behind the creation of the inverted "N" letter, and one of the main perks of the alternate Letter 36, as discussed at the top of page 15.

I do see the possibility of confusing my backwards "L" with "K", now that you mention it.  I didn't foresee that.  However,  for it to be genuinely confusing, I'd have to have poor discipline when it comes to letter height and maintaining each letter within its appropriate vertical boundaries, and I think I'm pretty careful about that.


I'm impressed that some of you have been knowledgeable about Quikscript and using it since shortly after its genesis!

                       Dave S
